chunks.original_latin:
SANCTI MARTINI
TRINAE UNITATIS ET UNIUS TRINITATIS
CONFESSIO.
chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
    The Confession of Saint Martin on the Trinity of the Unity and the Unity of the Trinity
</speak>

The compassionate Trinity is one divinity, known through the sacrament: unity comes from Him who is holy and spirit. From Him, who is the only begotten, existing in divine nature, light, and spirit. From Himself, through nature, through the substance of majesty, power, virtue, and divine light. One Spirit in two, and both in the same: Father in the Son, Son in the Father, in the Holy Spirit.

Thus, in three persons, we confess the body of knowledge: which above all, encompasses everything. In this mystery, we believe that all things arose from nothing. A mystery the human mind cannot comprehend, nor can an eloquent tongue explain. Nor can extensive discourse, even if it filled the whole world with books, explain divine knowledge. He who is indescribable cannot be described or comprehended, neither in word nor substance of His own divinity. He is the source of divine light, of light, of His own substance, nature. Let the eloquent tongue be silent, for speech fails about the indescribable: when the human mind has finished speaking of divine majesty, then it begins.

However great divine mercy is, no one knows, except He who begot: and no one discovers the secrets of the Father, except He who by nature, lost the beginning of being born. Therefore, let all meekness and modesty of the learned turn to the prophet, and presume by the Lord's authority, saying: Psalms 116:10. I believed, therefore I spoke.

Through the mystery, the profession is simple, as the foundation of the Church, solidified by Apostolic authority. Let the following predestination presume, saying. Henceforth let no one trouble me, I believe in Christ, and Him crucified. Because when he confesses the Son of Man, he also confesses the Holy Spirit: because from the Holy Spirit, and Mary the virgin, the mediator is born. When he confesses the firstborn, it is necessary to speak of the only begotten, who testifies that He is one and only without origin: the third person he confesses as the Father, existing in divine nature, light.
chunks.original_latin:
Clemens Trinitas est una divinitas, ut autem per
sacramentum cognoscatur: unitas est  ab eo qui est
sanctus, et spiritus: a quo, qui est, et unigenitus
sic exsistens divinae naturae, lucis, spiritus, a se,
se per naturam, per substantiam majestatis, potestatis,
virtutis, divinae lucis. Spiritus unus in duobus,
et uterque in id ipsum: pater in filio, filius in patre,
in sancto Spiritu. Sic tribus personis, confitemur
 corpus praescientiae: quod super omnia, cuncta
concludit. In hoc mysterium ergo credimus, esse ex
nullis exstantibus cuncta orta, quod mysterium mens
humana concipere non potest, nec oratoria lingua
enarrare, neque diffusi sermonis bibliothecarum volumina,
si totum mundum libri repleant, divina
scientia non possit inenarrabilis enarrari: qui est
indicibilis, nullo modo possit describi, neque concludi
 aut verbum aut substantia propria divinitatis
suae. Qui est fons divinae lucis, luminis, suae substantiae,
naturae. Sileat lingua oratoria, quia deficit
sermo de indicibili: cum consummaverit mens humana
de divina majestate dicere, tunc incipit. Quanta
sit autem divina clementia, nemo scit, nisi qui
 genuit: et nemo comperit secreta patris, nisi is qui
per naturam, nascendi initium amisit. Omnis ergo
mansuetudo et modestia peritorum, convertatur ad
prophetam: et dominica auctoritate praesumat, dicendo:
Credidi, propter quod locutus sum (Psal. CXV,
10). Quod autem per mysterium simplex sit professio,
ut fundamentum Ecclesiae, solidatae Apostolica auctoritate,
praedestinatio sequens praesumat, dicendo. De caetero nemo mihi molestus sit, ego credo in
Christum, et hunc crucifixum. Quia cum confitetur
filium hominis, confitetur et sanctum Spiritum:
quia e sancto Spiritu, et Maria virgine mediator
nascitur: cum confitetur primogenitum, necesse est
de unigenito, qui testimonium dicat, unum et solum
sine origine esse:  tertiam personam patrem confitetur,
exsistentem divinae naturae, lucis.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: The Spirit, as I mentioned, is unified in the divine nature, being one in two, and each within the same. The Father is in the Son, the Son is in the Father, all within the Holy Spirit, and the holy Church. Now and forever and ever. Amen.
chunks.original_latin:
Spiritus
 ut dixi, qui secundum divinam naturam, ut supra
dixi, est unus in duobus, et uterque in id ipsum;
pater in filio, filius in patre, in sancto Spiritu  in
sancta Ecclesia. Nunc et in immortalia saecula saeculorum. Amen.<span class="text-blue-600 font-bold"
